project.name: devrel
project.description: The Gentoo Developer Relations Project is an effort to recruit, train, and maintain developers for the various Gentoo projects.

longdescription.p: Gentoo Developer Relations is a project in Gentoo which aims to be a point of contact for prospective developers, as well as a point of contact for current developers. For prospective developers, we use the mailing lists, the forums and the Gentoo bug tracker to watch for, and invite, prospective developers.

goals.p: The stated goal for Gentoo Developer Relations is to act as a meeting point for Gentoo developers and advanced users both. As such, Gentoo Developer Relations is concerned with both intra-developer relations as well as forming relations with advanced users and prospective developers.

extraproject.name: Recruitment and Training
extraproject.p: Currently, we have a process on the Gentoo bug tracker which tracks a new developer's progress from initial contact through training and final sign up. As part of a new developer's training, they must fulfill several requirements, culminating in a quiz/questionnaire. Every new developer is assigned to a mentor on the Gentoo development team.

extraproject.name: Developer Conflict Resolution
extraproject.p: Grant Goodyear recently proposed a GLEP (Gentoo Linux Enhancement Proposal) calling for an Ombudsman to aid in developer conflict resolution. We would like to implement this plan in the near future. Also pro-active policies that are aimed at preventing technical/interpersonal conflicts will be developed; set channels of communication will also be developed in which developers can voice concerns (anything from technical disagreements to developer burnout) confidentially before these concerns degenerate into personal conflicts.

extraproject.name: Recruitment Policy
extraproject.p: One of the biggest questions in the user community is how to become a Gentoo Developer. We will attempt to outline our requirements for a prospective developer as well as provide an interface for prospective developers to contact the recruitment and training team. The requirements outline will include both etiquette and development guidelines for developers. One idea would be to create a comprehensive Developers' Handbook to cover everything from development policy through etiquette expectations to conflict resolution.
